title: Month-End Scheduling for Business Users
text: Create schedule first three months 2023, allowing non-working days Auckland Council.
code: library(mendr) # Create a calendar of Auckland Council's known non-working days create_calendar()  # Create a data frame of tasks and offsets. Alternatively, you could # read in an Excel file here.  tasks <- data.frame(    tasks = c("Send email reminder", "Extract data", "Run report"),    offsets = c(-2, 0, 1)    )  # Pass the data frame to `create_schedule` to create a schedule for the first # three months of 2023 create_schedule(   schedule_data = tasks,   starting_month = "2023-01",   iterations = 3   ) #>         date #> 1 2022-12-22 #> 2 2023-01-09 #> 3 2023-01-10 #> 4 2023-01-27 #> 5 2023-02-01 #> 6 2023-02-02 #> 7 2023-02-27 #> 8 2023-03-01 #> 9 2023-03-02

Create a calendar of non-working days — create_calendar
text: holidays vector Dates contains non-working days. default, returns list non-working days staff Auckland Council. weekend character vector days weekends. accepts: sunday, monday, tuesday, wednesday, thursday, friday, saturday. default, Saturday Sunday assumed days weekend.

title: Create a calendar of non-working days — create_calendar
code: # A calendar of non-working days for the first Quarter of 2023, with weekends # set to the default (Saturdays and Sundays) q1_2023 <- c(   seq(as.Date("2023-01-02"), as.Date("2023-01-06"), by = "days"),   as.Date("2023-01-30"),   as.Date("2023-02-06") ) create_calendar(holidays = q1_2023)

text: schedule_data data frame least two columns, first type character (tasks) second type integer (offsets). third column present, type character (email addresses). starting_month character string format yyyy-mm providing starting month schedule. iterations integer specifying number months wish schedule. default 1. filepath file name write

title: Create a schedule of tasks — create_schedule
text: tibble() three columns length equal number rows data frame multiplied iterations.

title: Create a schedule of tasks — create_schedule
text: first column data frame contain list tasks, example "Send email reminder" "Export data". column named task, need first column data frame. second column data frame contain list integers, might positive negative, define number working days relative first working day month. example, 0 first working day month, 1 second working day month . Alternatively, -1 day first working day month, -2 two days first working day month etc. column named offset, need second column data frame. third column data frame, optional, contain list email addresses individuals tasks assigned. task assigned one individual, separate email addresses semi-colon (;). column named assigned_to, need third column data frame choose include .

title: Create a schedule of tasks — create_schedule
code: # Create a calendar of Auckland Council's known non-working days create_calendar()  # Create a data frame of tasks and offsets tasks <- data.frame(   tasks = c("Send email reminder", "Extract data", "Run report"),   offsets = c(-2, 0, 1) )  # Pass the data frame to `create_schedule` to create a schedule for the first # three months of 2023 create_schedule(   schedule_data = tasks,   starting_month = "2023-01",   iterations = 3 ) #>                 tasks offsets       date #> 1 Send email reminder      -2 2022-12-22 #> 2        Extract data       0 2023-01-09 #> 3          Run report       1 2023-01-10 #> 4 Send email reminder      -2 2023-01-27 #> 5        Extract data       0 2023-02-01 #> 6          Run report       1 2023-02-02 #> 7 Send email reminder      -2 2023-02-27 #> 8        Extract data       0 2023-03-01 #> 9          Run report       1 2023-03-02
